{{DEFAULTSORT:Sequoyah}} [[Category:1770s births]] [[Category:1843 deaths]] [[Category:1840s missing person cases]] [[Category:American blacksmiths]] [[Category:American inventors]] [[Category:American people with disabilities]] [[Category:American silversmiths]] [[Category:Creators of writing systems]] [[Category:Cherokee people]] [[Category:Cherokee Nation (1794–1907)]] [[Category:Missing person cases in Mexico]] [[Category:Native Americans in the War of 1812]] [[Category:People from Knox County, Tennessee]] [[Category:People from Tennessee in the War of 1812]] [[Category:People of the Creek War]] [[Category:People of the Indian Territory]] [[Category:18th-century Native Americans]]

The '''South Trafford Archaeological Group''' (STAG) is an archaeological group based in [[Timperley]], [[Greater Manchester]]. The group promotes interest in and the study of archaeology and history locally, especially within [[Trafford]] but also beyond the borders of the borough.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.trafford.gov.uk/communitygroups/Organisation.aspx?GroupID=191 |publisher=Trafford Metropolitan Borough Council |title=South Trafford Archaeological Group |accessdate=25 April 2008}}</ref> Its activities include post-excavation work and [[documentary research]].<ref name="currentarch">{{citation |url=http://www.archaeology.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1194&Itemid=80 |author=[[Current Archaeology]] |title=South Trafford Archaeological Group |publisher=CurrentArchaeology.co.uk |accessdate=25 April 2008}}</ref>
STAG was formed in 1979 and provides facilities for volunteer archaeologists from south Manchester and north-east Cheshire.<ref name="currentarch"/><ref name="stag homepage">{{citation |url=http://homepage.ntlworld.com/bryan.burtonbj |title=South Trafford Archaeological Group |publisher=South Trafford Archaeological Group |date=29 May 2007 |accessdate=30 July 2007}}</ref> It has 95 members and is based near the site of [[Timperley Hall|Timperley Old Hall]] – a medieval [[moat]]ed hall – and the clubhouse of the Altrincham Municipal Golf Course.<ref name="currentarch"/><ref name="stag homepage"/> STAG has undertaken excavations as far away as ''Condate'', the [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] name for [[Northwich]], in Cheshire.<ref>{{citation |url=http://pastscape.english-heritage.org.uk/events.aspx?a=0&hob_id=72996 |title=Condate, investigation history |publisher=Pastscape.org.uk |accessdate=26 April 2008}}</ref> The group has been involved with sites such as Timperley Old Hall; Carrs Mill in [[Stalybridge]]; Moore's hat factory in [[Denton, Greater Manchester|Denton]]; the medieval hall in [[Urmston]]; and Moss Brow farm in [[Warburton, Greater Manchester|Warburton]].<ref>{{citation |url=http://homepage.ntlworld.com/bryan.burtonbj/projects.htm |title=S.T.A.G. projects |publisher=South Trafford Archaeological Group |date=29 May 2007 |accessdate=30 July 2007}}</ref> The excavations in Warburton led to the site being excavated by ''[[Time Team]]'' in 2006 with the involvement of STAG.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.thisischeshire.co.uk/display.var.1222777.0.teams_dig_takes_them_back_in_time.php |first=Lynsey |last=Roberts |title=Team's dig takes them back in time |publisher=ThisIsCheshire.co.uk |date=28 February 2007 |accessdate=25 April 2008}}</ref>
In 2008, STAG was awarded £44,400 by the [[Heritage Lottery Fund]] to renovate the site of Timperley Old Hall. The work will involve installing a bridge across the moat, installing information boards on the site, and developing an information scheme for local schools. It will also allow new archaeological investigations to be performed on the site.<ref name="lottery">{{citation |url= http://www.hlf.org.uk/ourproject/Pages/Oct2007/4244e5d6-3c9c-43bd-b090-5dcb5d1128fd.aspx |agency= Heritage Lottery Fund |title= Project: Your history, your heritage |publisher= hlf.org.uk |year= 2008 |accessdate=28 May 2010}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Stockport Heritage]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.stag-archaeology.uk South Trafford Archaeology Group website]

revision.text:
[[File:Jagadguru Rambhadracharya at Baroda.JPG|thumb|alt=Rambhadracharya|Rambhadracharya delivering a sermon in Baroda, Gujarat, India.]] {{Rambhadracharya sidebar}}
This timeline lists important events relevant to the life of the Vaishnava (Hindu) saint, poet, commentator, educationist, religious and social figure '''[[Rambhadracharya]]''' (1950 – ''present'').
Jagadguru Ramanandacharya was born on 14 January 1950 as '''Giridhar Mishra'''.<ref name="speakerloksabha"/> He is one of four incumbent ''Jagadguru Ramanandacharya'',<ref group="lower-greek">Leaders of the [[Ramanandi sect|Ramananda monastic order]].</ref> and has held this title since 1988.<ref name="kbs-bio"/><ref name="agarwal-bio">Agarwal 2010, pp. 1108–1110.</ref><ref name="dinkarjagadguru">Dinkar 2008, p. 32.</ref>
He is the establisher and head of Tulsi Peeth, a religious and social service institution named after saint [[Tulsidas]], located in Chitrakoot.<ref>Nagar 2002, p. 91.</ref><ref name="the-eye"/> He is the founder and lifelong chancellor of the [[Jagadguru Rambhadracharya Handicapped University]] in Chitrakoot, which offers graduate and postgraduate courses exclusively to four types of disabled students.<ref name="speakerloksabha"/><ref>Dwivedi 2008, p. x.</ref><ref name="aicb-p68">Aneja 2005, p. 68.</ref><ref name="bhartiyapaksha"/> Rambhadracharya has been blind since the age of two months. He has never used [[Braille]] or any other aid to learn or compose.<ref name="aicb-p67">Aneja 2005, p. 67.</ref>
Rambhadracharya can speak 22 languages, and is a spontaneous poet,<ref group="lower-greek">''Ashukavi''.</ref> and writer in Sanskrit, [[Hindi]], [[Awadhi language|Awadhi]], [[Maithili language|Maithili]], and several other languages.<ref name="kkbvp"/><ref name="dinkar-polyglot">Dinkar 2008, p. 39.</ref> He has composed more than 90 works, including four epic poems,<ref group="lower-greek">Two each in [[Sanskrit]] and Hindi.</ref> a Hindi commentary on Tulsidas' [[Ramcharitmanas]], a Sanskrit commentary in verse on the [[Ashtadhyayi]], and Sanskrit commentaries on the [[Prasthanatrayi]] scriptures.<ref name="rcm-judgement"/><ref name="dinkarbiblio">Dinkar 2008, pp. 40–43.</ref> He is regarded as one of the greatest authorities on Tulsidas in India,<ref name="prasad-on-jr"/> and is the editor of a [[Textual criticism|critical edition]] of the Ramcharitmanas.<ref>Rambhadracharya (ed) 2006.</ref> He is ''[[Katha (storytelling format)|Katha]]'' artist for the [[Ramayana]] and the [[Bhagavata Purana|Bhagavata]]. His ''Katha'' programmes are held regularly in different cities in India and other countries, and are telecast on television channels like [[Sanskar TV]] and Sanatan TV.<ref name="programmes"/><ref name="sitanavmi"/>
==Timeline==
'''1950''' :''January 14'':Born as Giridhar Mishra in Shandikhurd village of [[Jaunpur district]] to mother Shachidevi and father Pandit Rajdev Mishra.<ref name="bhartiyapaksha"/><ref name="nagarearlylife">Nagar 2002, pp. 37–53.</ref><ref name="aicb-p66">Aneja 2005, p. 66.</ref> :''March 24'':Eyes got infected by [[trachoma]].<ref name="bhartiyapaksha"/><ref name="nagarearlylife"/><ref name="aicb-p66"/>
'''1953''' :Composed his first piece of poetry—in Awadhi (a dialect of Hindi).<ref name="nagarearlylife"/><ref>Prasad 1999, p. 133.</ref> :''June'':Had a near-death experience when fell in a small dry well.<ref name="nagarearlylife"/><ref name="dinkarearlylife">Dinkar 2008, pp. 22–24.</ref>
'''1955''' :Memorised the entire [[Bhagavad Gita]].<ref name="bhartiyapaksha"/> :''[[Janmashtami]]'':Recited the entire Bhagavad Gita.<ref name="nagarearlylife"/>
'''1957''' :Memorised the entire [[Ramcharitmanas]].<ref name="bhartiyapaksha"/> :''[[Rama Navami]]'':Recited the entire Ramcharitmanas while fasting.<ref name="nagarearlylife"/><ref name="dinkarearlylife"/>
'''1961''' :Had his ''[[Upanayana]]'' performed and given the [[Gayatri Mantra]].<ref name="dinkarearlylife"/> :Was stopped from joining his family in a wedding procession due to his disability.<ref name="nagarearlylife"/><ref name="aicb-p66"/>
'''1967''' :''July 7'' - Joined the Adarsh Gaurishankar Sanskrit College.<ref name="dinkaredu">Dinkar 2008, pp. 25–27.</ref>
'''1971''' :Enrolled at the [[Sampurnanand Sanskrit University]].<ref name="dinkaredu"/>
'''1974''' :Topped the final examination for the Shastri (Bachelor of Arts) degree in Sanskrit grammar :Won five gold medals at the ''Akhila Bharatiya Sanskrit Adhiveshan''.<ref name="kbs-bio"/><ref name="gupta-kumar-ssu">Gupta and Kumar 2006, p. 745.</ref><ref name="parauha"/>
'''1976''' :Topped the final examination for the Acharya (Master of Arts) degree in Sanskrit grammar.<ref name="parauha">{{cite book |last=Parauha |first=Tulsidas |editor-last=Rambhadracharya |editor-first=Svami |pages=5–9 |date=14 January 2011 |title=गीतरामायणम् (गीतसीताभिरामं संस्कृतगीतमहाकाव्यम्) |trans-title=Gītarāmāyaṇam (The Gītasītābhirāmam Sanskrit lyrical epic poem) |chapter=महाकविजगद्गुरुस्वामिरामभद्राचार्याणां व्यक्तित्वं कृतित्वञ्च |trans-chapter=The life and works of the great poet Jagadguru Rambhadracharya |language=Sanskrit |publisher=Jagadguru Rambhadracharya Handicapped University}}</ref> :Narrated a Katha on Ramcharitmanas to [[Swami Karpatri]].<ref name="vaishnava1916">{{cite book | editor1-first = Daniel Coit | editor1-last=Gilman | editor2-first=Harry Thurston | editor2-last=Peck | editor3-first=Frank Moore | editor3-last=Calby | year=1916 | title = New International Encyclopædia: Volume XXII | publisher=Dodd, Mead and Company | edition=Second | location = New York, New York, United States of America | url = https://archive.org/details/newinternationa35unkngoog | accessdate=9 October 2011 | page=847}}</ref><ref name="dinkarlaterlife">Dinkar 2008, pp. 28–31.</ref> :Won gold medal for standing first in all-India Sanskrit debate competition and a Chancellor's Gold Medal from by the Sampurnanand Sanskrit University.<ref name="parauha"/><ref>Nagar 2002, p. 78.</ref> :''April 30'' - Was declared Acharya of all subjects taught at the Sampurnanand Sanskrit University.<ref name="aicb-p67"/>
'''1979''' :Observed his first ''[[Payovrata]]''.<ref name="dinkarlaterlife"/><ref>Poddar 1996, p. 10.</ref>
'''1980''' :Wrote a Hindi minor poem ''Kākā Vidura'', a Sanskrit minor poem ''Mukundasmaraṇam'' and a Hindi discourse ''Bharata Mahimā''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio">Dinkar 2008, pp. 40–43.</ref><ref name="nagar89">Nagar 2002, pp. 89–90.</ref>
'''1981''' :Wrote a Sanskrit dissertation (PhD thesis) ''Adhyātmarāmāyaṇe Apāṇinīyaprayogānāṃ Vimarśaḥ''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :''October 14'' - Completed his Vidyavaridhi degree in Sanskrit grammar.<ref name="aicb-p67"/>
'''1982''' :Wrote a Hindi minor poem ''Mā̐ Śabarī'' and a Hindi deliberation ''Mānasa Me̐ Tāpasa Prasaṅga''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''1983''' :Wrote a Hindi commentary on [[Hanuman Chalisa]] ''Mahavīrī''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :''November 19'' - Took ''Virakta Diksha'' in the [[Ramanandi sect|Ramananda Sampradaya]].<ref name="dinkarlaterlife"/>
'''1985''' :Wrote a Hindi discourse ''Sugrīva Kā Agha Aura Vibhīṣaṇa Kī Karatūti'' and a Hindi commentary on the [[Bhagavad Gita]] ''Śrīgītātātparya''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''1987''' :Established a religious and social service institution called Tulsi Peeth.<ref name="the-eye"/> :Wrote a Sanskrit hymn of praise ''Śrījānakīkṛpākaṭākṣastotram''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''1988''' :Wrote a Hindi deliberation ''Sanātanadharma Kī Vigrahasvarūpa Gomātā'' and a Hindi investigative research ''Śrītulasīsāhitya me̐ Kṛṣṇa Kathā''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :''June 24'' - Chosen as the ''Jagadguru Ramanandacharya'' seated at the Tulsi Peeth.<ref name="dinkarjagadguru">Dinkar 2008, p. 32.</ref>
'''1989''' :Wrote a Hindi discourse ''Mānasa me̐ Sumitrā''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''1990''' :Wrote a Hindi critique ''Sīta Nirvāsana Nahī̐''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''1991''' :Wrote a Sanskrit commentary on the [[Narada Bhakti Sutra]] ''Śrīnāradabhaktisūtreṣu Śrīrāghavakṛpābhāṣyam''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''1992''' :Wrote a Sanskrit hymn of praise ''Śrīrāmavallabhāstotram'' and a Hindi discourse ''Prabhu Kari Kṛpā Pā̐varī Dīnhī''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''1993''' :Wrote a Hindi lyrical poem ''Bhaktigītasudhā'' and a Hindi discourse ''Parama Baḍabhāgī Jaṭāyu''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''1994''' :Wrote a Hindi epic poem ''[[Arundhati (epic)|Arundhatī]]''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :Wrote a Sanskrit hymn of praise ''Śrīgaṅgāmahimnastotram''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''1995''' :Wrote a Sanskrit hymn of praise ''Śrīcitrakūṭavihāryaṣṭakam''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :''August 1'' - Ritually anointed as the ''Jagadguru Ramanandacharya''.<ref name="kbs-bio"/>
'''1996''' :Wrote a Sanskrit minor poem ''Ājādacandraśekharacaritam''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :Wrote a Single-act Sanskrit play-poem ''Śrīrāghavābhyudayam''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :''August 23'' - Established the Tulsi School for the Blind.<ref name="the-eye"/><ref name="aicb-p68"/>
'''1997''' :Wrote a Sanskrit commentary ''Aṣṭādhyāyyāḥ Pratisūtraṃ Śābdabodhasamīkṣaṇam''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :Wrote a Sanskrit poem ''Śrīrāmabhaktisarvasvam''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :''May 9'' - Was awarded the post-doctorate Vachaspati (DLitt) degree by Sampurnanand Sanskrit University.<ref name="gupta-kumar-ssu"/><ref name="Bhuyan-2002">Bhuyan 2002, p. 245.</ref>
'''1998''' :Got the title of ''Dharmachakravarti'' by the World Religious Parliament.<ref name="kbs-awards">Chandra 2008, p. 21.</ref><ref>Nagar 2002, p. 182.</ref>
'''1999''' :Won the ''Kaviraj Vidya Narayan Shastri Archana-Samman Award'' from the Kaviraj Vidya Narayan Shastri Archana-Samman Committee, Bhagalpur and the ''Mahakavi'' title by the Akhil Bharatiya Hindi Bhasha Sammelan, Bihar.<ref>Nagar 2002, p. 184.</ref><ref>Nagar 2002, p. 183.</ref>
'''2000''' :Won the ''Vishishta Puraskar'' from the Uttar Pradesh Sanskrit Samsthana, Lucknow and the ''Mahamahopadhyay'' title by the [[Lal Bahadur Shastri]] Sanskrit Vidyapeeth, New Delhi.<ref name="kbs-awards"/><ref name="Vidyapeetha-4">{{cite web |url=http://www.slbsrsv.ac.in/newconvocation.asp |title=Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri Rashtriya Sanskrit Vidyapeetha – Convocation |publisher=Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri Rashtriya Sanskrit Vidyapeetha |accessdate=11 June 2011 |quote=The Fourth Convocation of the Vidyapeetha was organized on 11th of February, 2000. ... Honorary title of Mahamahopadhyaya was conferred on Shri Swami Rambhadracharya (U.P.), ... by the Chancellor.}}</ref> :Wrote a Sanskrit minor poem ''Sarayūlaharī''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''2001''' :Wrote a Sanskrit minor poem ''Laghuraghuvaram''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :''September 27'' - Founded the [[Jagadguru Rambhadracharya Handicapped University]].<ref name="aicb-p68"/><ref name="bhartiyapaksha"/>
'''2002''' :Won the ''Kavikularatna'' title from Sampurnanand Sanskrit University, Varanasi.<ref name="kbs-awards"/> :Wrote a Sanskrit epic poem ''[[Sribhargavaraghaviyam|Śrībhārgavarāghavīyam]]'', a Sanskrit minor poem ''Śrīrāghavabhāvadarśanam'', a Sanskrit commentary on the Rāmastavarājastotra ''Śrīrāmastavarājastotre Śrīrāghavakṛpābhāṣyam'' and a Hindi discourse ''Śrī Sītārāma Vivāha Darśana''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''2003''' :Won the ''Rajshekhar Samman'' from the Madhya Pradesh Sanskrit Academy, Bhopal, the ''Bhaurao Deoras Award'' by the Bhaurao Deoras Seva Nyas, Lucknow, the ''Diwaliben Award'' by the Dewaliben Mehta Charitable Trust, Mumbai and the ''Ativishishta Puraskar'' by the Uttar Pradesh Sanskrit Samsthana, Lucknow.<ref name="kbs-awards"/><ref>Sharma et al 2011, p. 840.</ref><ref name="tnn">{{cite news |date=17 March 2003 |title=Bhaurao Samman for Dattopanth Thengadi |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2003-03-17/lucknow/27275780_1_award-honour-sangh-workers |work=The Times of India |location=India |agency=TNN |accessdate=27 May 2011}}</ref><ref name="Bhaurao">{{cite news |date=30 March 2003 |url=http://www.panchjanya.com/30-3-2003/20back.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20030504102726/http://www.panchjanya.com/30-3-2003/20back.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 May 2003 |title=जगद्गुरु स्वामी रामभद्राचार्य तथा वरिष्ठ चिंतक दत्तोपंत ठेंगडी को भाऊराव देवरस सेवा सम्मान – वैभवशाली राष्ट्र के निर्माण का आह्वान |trans-title=Bhaurao Devras Honour for Jagadguru Swami Rambhadracharya and eminent philosopher Dattopant Thengdi – Call for building a glorious nation |language=Hindi |work=Panchjanya |accessdate=29 April 2011}}</ref> :Wrote a Sanskrit letter poem ''Kubjāpatram''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :''July'' - Deposed as an expert witness in the [[Ayodhya dispute|Ram Janmabhoomi Babri Masjid dispute]] case in the [[Allahabad High Court]].<ref name="Sharma-2003">{{cite news |last=Sharma |first=Amit |date=1 May 2003 |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/oldStory/23063/ |title=No winners in VHP's Ayodhya blame game |work=The Indian Express |location=India |accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="Mid-day-2003-07-17">{{cite news |date=17 July 2003 |url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2003/jul/58790.htm |title=Babar destroyed Ram temple at Ayodhya |work=Mid-Day |accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="Mid-day-2003-07-21"> {{cite news |work=Mid-Day |date=21 July 2003 |url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2003/jul/59146.htm |title=Ram Koop was constructed by Lord Ram |accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref>
'''2004''' :Won the Awadh Ratna title from the Awadh Vikas Parishad, Allahabad and the Badarayana Puraskar.<ref name="kbs-awards"/><ref>Sharma et al 2011, p. 837.</ref> :Wrote a Sanskrit minor poem ''[[Bhrngadutam|Bhṛṅgadūtam]]'' and a Hindi discourse ''Tuma Pāvaka Ma̐ha Karahu Nivāsā''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''2005''' :Wrote a Hindi commentary on the Ramcharitmanas ''Bhāvārthabodhinī''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :Won the [[Sahitya Akademi Award for Sanskrit]] for ''[[Sribhargavaraghaviyam|Śrībhārgavarāghavīyam]]''.<ref name="dna205">{{cite web | last=Press Trust of India | publisher=DNA India | title = Kolatkar, Dalal among Sahitya Akademi winners | url = http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_kolatkar-dalal-among-sahitya-akademi-winners_1003524 | date = 22 December 2005 | accessdate=24 June 2011}}</ref>
'''2006''' :Won the Sanskrit Mahamahopadhyay title from the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan, Prayag, the Shreevani Alankaran award from the Jaydayal Dalmiya Shri Vani Trust and the Banabhatta Award from the Madhya Pradesh Sanskrit Board, Bhopal.<ref name="speakerloksabha"/><ref name="kkbvp"/><ref name="kbs-awards"/> :Wrote a Hindi discourse ''Ahalyoddhāra''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''2007''' :Won the Goswami Tulsidas Samarchan Samman from the Tulsi Research Institute, Municipal Corporation, [[Allahabad]] and the ''Vachaspati Award'' by the [[K. K. Birla Foundation]], New Delhi.<ref name="kbs-awards"/><ref name="the-hindu">{{cite news |author=Special Correspondent |date=20 February 2008 |url=http://www.hindu.com/2008/02/20/stories/2008022051411300.htm |title=Selected for Birla Foundation awards |work=The Hindu |location=India |accessdate=24 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="Birla">{{cite web |last=Special Correspondent |date=19 April 2008 |url=http://www.hindu.com/2008/04/19/stories/2008041954260500.htm |title=K.K. Birla Foundation awards presented |work=The Hindu |location=India |accessdate =24 June 2011}}</ref> :Wrote a Hindi deliberation on ''Rāsapañcādhyāyī'' ''Śrīrāsapañcādhyāyīvimarśaḥ''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :''November 27'' - Received a letter telling him and his disciples either to accept [[Islam]] or to be prepared to die.<ref name=alqaeda>{{cite web|url=http://hindi.webdunia.com/news/news/regional/0711/30/1071130097_1.htm|title=अल कायदा ने दी कुलाधिपति को धमकी|language=Hindi|publisher=Webduniya Hindi|date=November 30, 2007|trans-title=Al-Qaeda threatens the Chancellor|accessdate=October 12, 2012}}</ref> :''November 30'' - Released the first Braille version of the Bhagavad Gita.<ref name="Zee-2007">{{cite news |date=3 December 2007 |url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/lifestyle/bhagwad-gita-in-braille-language_411003.html |title=Bhagavad Gita in Braille Language |work=Webdunia Hindi |agency=Asian News International |accessdate=2 July 2011}}</ref>
'''2008''' :Wrote a Hindi discourse ''Ahalyoddhāra''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :Wrote a Hindi Rītikāvya ''Hara Te Bhe Hanumāna''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/>
'''2009''' :Wrote a Sanskrit [[suprabhatam]] ''[[Srisitaramasuprabhatam|Śrīsītārāmasuprabhātam]]''.<ref name="dinkarbiblio"/><ref name="nagar89"/> :''November'' - Accused of tampering with the Ramcharitmanas.<ref name="toi-fia">{{cite news | title = Fury in Ayodhya over Ramcharitmanas | url = http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-11-01/india/28068936_1_seers-editions-disciples | accessdate =25 April 2011 | date = 1 November 2009 |work=The Times of India |location=India | first1=Manjari | last1=Mishra | first2=V. N. | last2=Arora}}</ref><ref name="dispute-deepens">{{cite news |date=3 November 2009 |url=http://hindi.webdunia.com/news/news/regional/0911/03/1091103099_1.htm |title=रामचरित मानस से जुड़ा विवाद गहराया |trans-title=Dispute associated with Ramcharitmanas deepens |language=Hindi |work=Webdunia |accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref>
'''2010''' :Wrote a Hindi epic poem ''[[Ashtavakra (epic)|Aṣṭāvakra]]''.<ref name="Ashtavakra">{{cite book |title=Aṣṭāvakra Mahākāvya |trans-title=The Epic Ashtavakra |first=Jagadguru |last=Rambhadracharya | language=Hindi |location=Chitrakuta |publisher=Jagadguru Rambhadracharya Handicapped University |date=14 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="Bhaskar-2010">{{cite news | publisher=Dainik Bhaskar | title=वक्ताओं ने कही अपनी बात | trans-title=Orators speak out their views | language=Hindi | url=http://bollywood2.bhaskar.com/article/MP-OTH-997126-1582386.html | date=25 November 2010 | accessdate=9 September 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402090650/http://bollywood2.bhaskar.com/article/MP-OTH-997126-1582386.html | archivedate=2 April 2012 | df= }}</ref>
'''2011''' :Won the ''Tulsi Award 2011'' from [[Morari Bapu]] and the ''Dev Bhumi Award'' from the Government of [[Himachal Pradesh]], [[Shimla]].<ref>Mishra 2011, p. 24.</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Durg | first=City Reporter | location=Bhilai, Chhattisgarh, India | title=नेत्रहीन आचार्य की भागवत कथा आज से | trans-title=Bhagavata Katha by visually impaired preceptor starts today | date=30 October 2011 | url=http://www8.bhaskar.com/article/CHH-OTH-1599867-2529829.html | language=Hindi | accessdate=29 November 2011 | publisher=Dainik Bhaskar | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129024526/http://www.bhaskar.com/article/CHH-OTH-1599867-2529829.html | archivedate=29 November 2011 | df= }}</ref><ref name="prlog">{{cite news |date=4 March 2011 |url=http://www.prlog.org/11352079-himachal-pradesh-state-level-award-for-sandeep-marwah.html |title=Himachal Pradesh State Level Award For Sandeep Marwah |work=PRLog |accessdate=5 March 2011}}</ref> :Wrote a Sanskrit lyrical epic poem ''[[Gitaramayanam|Gītarāmāyaṇam]]'', a Awadhi lyrical poem ''Avadha Kai Ajoriyā'' and a Sanskrit minor poem ''Śrīsītāsudhānidhiḥ''.<ref name="stps-gr">Sushil & Mishra 2011, p. 14</ref><ref name="Awadha">{{cite book |last=Rambhadracharya |first=Jagadguru |year=2011 |title=अवध कै अजोरिया |trans-title=The moonlight of Awadha |language=Awadhi |location=Chitrakuta |publisher=Jagadguru Rambhadracharya Handicapped University}}</ref><ref name="ocean-of-nectar">{{cite book |last=Rambhadracharya |first=Jagadguru |date=15 July 2011 |title=श्रीसीतासुधानिधिः |trans-title=The ocean of nectar of Sita |language=Sanskrit |location=Chitrakuta |publisher=Jagadguru Rambhadracharya Handicapped University}}</ref>
'''2014''' :''November'' - Nominated by the [[Prime Minister of India|Indian Prime Minister]] [[Narendra Modi]] for the [[Swachh Bharat Abhiyan|Clean India Campaign]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-pm-narendra-modi-offers-prayers-at-assi-ghat-says-confident-that-ganga-will-be-cleaned-up-2033101 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20141108044747/http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-pm-narendra-modi-offers-prayers-at-assi-ghat-says-confident-that-ganga-will-be-cleaned-up-2033101 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=November 8, 2014 | accessdate=November 8, 2014 | date=November 8, 2014 | title=PM Narendra Modi offers prayers at Assi Ghat; says 'confident that Ganga will be cleaned up' | work=DNA }}</ref>
'''2015''' :''January 25'' - Awarded [[Padma Vibhushan]], India's second highest civilian honour.<ref>{{cite web|title=Padma Awards 2015|publisher=[[Press Information Bureau]]|url=http://www.pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=114952|accessdate=2015-01-25}}</ref>

{{About|the Victoria Memorial in Kolkata|other memorials to Queen Victoria|Victoria Memorial (disambiguation)}} {{EngvarB|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Coord|display=title|22.5449|88.3425}} {{Infobox museum | name = Victoria memorial | native_name = '''ভিক্টোরিয়া মেমোরিয়াল হল
विक्टोरिया मेमोरियल हॉल''' | image = Victoria Memorial situated in Kolkata.jpg | map_type = | map_caption = | latitude = | longitude = | established = {{Start date|1921|df=y}} | location = Queen's Way, Kolkata, WB, India | type = Museum | architect = [[William Emerson (British architect)|William Emerson]] | collection = Nearly 30,000 (31 March 2009)Government of India, Ministry of Culture, ''Annual report 2008–2009.'' p. 30 | visitors = | director = | publictransit = | website = {{URL|http://www.victoriamemorial-cal.org/|victoriamemorial-cal.org}} }} The '''Victoria Memorial''' is a large marble building in [[Kolkata]], [[West Bengal]], [[India]], which was built between 1906 and 1921. It is dedicated to the memory of [[Queen Victoria]] (1819–1901) and is now a museum and tourist destination under the auspices of the [[Ministry of Culture (India)|Ministry of Culture]].[http://www.iloveindia.com/indian-monuments/victoria-memorial.html Victoria Memorial]. ''www.iloveindia.com''. The memorial lies on the ''[[Maidan (Kolkata)|Maidan]]'' (grounds) by the bank of the [[Hooghly River]], near [[Jawaharlal Nehru Road]] (better known as Chowringhee Road).Vaughan P. [https://books.google.com/books?id=73IYAAAAYAAJ&q=victoria+memorial+museum+collections&dq=victoria+memorial+museum+collections&hl=en&sa=X&ei=CAqsUsjvIML2lAWdooCgBg&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBQ "The Victoria Memorial Hall, Calcutta: conception, collections, conservation."] Marg Publications, Nation Centre for the Performing Arts (India) 1997. Original from the University of Virginia. Digitized 7 April 2008. {{ISBN|8185026386}}, 9788185026381. Accessed at Google Books, 14 December 2013. [[File:Queen Victoria bw.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Queen Victoria]] == History == [[File:George Curzon2.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston|Lord Curzon]], Viceroy of India]] In January 1901, on the death of Queen Victoria,Lehman H. E. [https://books.google.com/books?id=d8VP0bIV-IwC&dq=queen+victoria+death+1901&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Lives of England's monarchs."] AuthorHouse, 2005. p390. {{ISBN|1-4184-9692-8}}, 9781418496920. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. [[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston|The 1st Baron Curzon of Kedleston]] (later created [[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston|The 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston]]), the then [[Viceroy of India]], suggested the creation of a fitting memorial. Lord Curzon proposed the construction of a grand building with a museum and gardens.Herbert E. W. [https://books.google.com/books?id=f_S9sNe8f7AC&dq=curzon+viceroy+india+victoria+memorial&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Flora's empire: British gardens in India."] Penn Studies in Landscape Architecture, University of Pennsylvania Press, 2012. p224. {{ISBN|0-8122-0505-7}}, 9780812205053. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. Curzon said, {{quote|"Let us, therefore, have a building, stately, spacious, monumental and grand, to which every newcomer in Calcutta will turn, to which all the resident population, European and Native, will flock, where all classes will learn the lessons of history, and see revived before their eyes the marvels of the past."Dutta K. [https://books.google.com/books?id=UKfoHi5412UC&dq=victoria+memorial+calcutta+opening&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Calcutta: a cultural and literary history."] S – 131. {{ISBN|1-902669-59-2}}, 9781902669595. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013.}} [[Prince of Wales|The Prince of Wales]], later [[George V|King George V]], laid the foundation stone on 4 January 1906, and it was formally opened to the public in 1921.[http://www.archive.india.gov.in/knowindia/culture_heritage.php?id=68] In 1912, before the construction of the Victoria Memorial was finished, [[King George V]] announced the transfer of the capital of India from Calcutta to [[New Delhi]].Gordon D. (ed.) [https://books.google.com/books?id=uxqUTnAdoP4C&dq=capital+india+calcutta+to+delhi&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Planning twentieth century capital cities."] Planning, History and Environment Series. Routledge, 2006 p182. {{ISBN|0-203-48156-9}}, 9780203481561. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. Thus, the Victoria Memorial was built in what would be a provincial city rather than a capital. == Finance == [[File:Victoria by nabarun.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Illumination.]] The Victoria Memorial was funded by Indian states, individuals of the [[British Raj]] and the British government in London. The princes and people of India responded generously to Lord Curzon's appeal for funds, and the total cost of construction of the monument, amounting to one crore, five lakhs of rupees, was entirely derived from their voluntary subscriptions.{{cite web|title=History of the Victoria Memorial Hall |url=http://www.victoriamemorial-cal.org/history.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030613111755/http://www.victoriamemorial-cal.org/history.html |archivedate=13 June 2003 |website=Official Website of the Victoria Memorial Hall}} == Design == [[File:Victoria memorial 000.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Victoria Memorial]] The Victoria Memorial's architect was [[William Emerson (British architect)|William Emerson]] (1843–1924), president of the [[Royal Institute of British Architects]].[http://www.kolkatainformation.com/calhert/v_mem.htm "Victoria Memorial."] ''www.kolkatainformation.com''.Kumar R. [https://books.google.com/books?id=BT77yuqxGj4C&dq=%22william+emerson%22+architect+india&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Essays on Indian art and architecture."] Discovery Publishing House, 2003. p16. {{ISBN|8171417159}}, 9788171417155. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. The design is in the [[Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture|Indo-Saracenic revivalist style]] which uses a mixture of British and [[Mughal architecture|Mughal]] elements with [[Venetian Gothic architecture|Venetian]], [[Ancient Egyptian architecture|Egyptian]], [[Deccan Plateau|Deccani]] and [[Islam]]ic architectural influences.Knight L. [https://books.google.com/books?id=NVfTufIqlD8C&dq=%22william+emerson%22+architect+india&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Britain in India, 1858 – 1947."] Anthem Press, 2012. p85. {{ISBN|0-85728-517-3}}, 9780857285171. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. The building is {{convert|338|ft|m}} by {{convert|228|ft|m}} and rises to a height of {{convert|184|ft|m}}. It is constructed of white [[Makrana marble]].Hermann M. [https://books.google.com/books?id=c8EDZqQqK2gC&dq=%22william+emerson%22+architect+india&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Architecture in India."] GRIN Verlag, 2011. {{ISBN|3-640-92977-2}}, 9783640929771. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. The gardens of the Victoria Memorial were designed by [[Lord Redesdale]] and [[David Prain]]. Emerson's assistant, [[Vincent Jerome Esch]], designed the bridge of the north aspect and the garden gates. === William Emerson === Emerson was a pupil of [[William Burges]] and an architectural theorist. He first visited India in about 1860. Emerson designed the [[Crawford Market]], [[Mumbai]] (1865),Chopra P is making the CA [https://books.google.com/books?id=jhTiCnh6RqAC&dq=%22william+emerson%22+architect+india&source=gbs_navlinks_s "A joint enterprise: Indian elites and the making of British Bombay."] U of Minnesota Press, 2011. p41 {{ISBN|0-8166-7036-6}}, 9780816670369. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. the [[All Saints Cathedral, Allahabad]] (1871),Sajnani M. [https://books.google.com/books?id=vdMNBxOsvrUC&dq=%22william+emerson%22+architect+india&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Encylopaedia of tourism resources in India."] Gyan Publishing House, 2001 p395 {{ISBN|8178350173}}, 9788178350172. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. and [[Allahabad University|Muir College]] (1873).Nayar P. K. [https://books.google.com/books?id=UiBcR9Xy7YwC&dq=%22william+emerson%22+architect+india&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Colonial voices: the discourses of empire."] John Wiley & Sons, 2012 p143. {{ISBN|1-118-27899-2}}, 9781118278994. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. Emerson moved to the princely state of [[Bhavnagar]], [[Gujarat]], and designed the [[Takhtsingji]] Hospital and the Nilambagh Palace. There, he learned to include [[Hinduism|Hindu]] architectural elements in his works.Desai M. et al [https://books.google.com/books?id=Re7ixChJUvUC&dq=%22william+emerson%22+architect+india&source=gbs_navlinks_s "The Bungalow in twentieth-century India: the cultural expression of changing ways of life and aspirations in the domestic architecture of colonial and post-colonial society."] Ashgate Publishing, Ltd., 2012. p128 {{ISBN|1-4094-2738-2}}, 9781409427384. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. === Vincent J. Esch === [[File:Statue of Queen Victoria in front of Victoria Memorial Hall, Calcutta.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Victoria]] In 1899, Esch was appointed assistant engineer at the [[Bengal Nagpur Railway]], a job which gave him much practical experience in large-scale construction and costings.Schama S. [https://books.google.com/books?id=V4RABT9O1uQC&dq=%22vincent+esch%22&source=gbs_navlinks_s "A History of Britain – volume 3: the fate of the empire 1776 – 2000."] Random House, 2012. {{ISBN|1-4090-1835-0}}, 9781409018353. Accessed at Google Books, 14 December 2013. In 1902, Emerson engaged Esch to sketch his original design for the Victoria Memorial. After designing the temporary exhibition building for the [[Delhi Durbar]] of 1903, Curzon found Esch to be a suitable assistant for Emerson.Morris J. [https://books.google.com/books?id=8zD1Ugfq9KwC&dq=%22vincent+esch%22&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Stones of the empire:the buildings of the Raj."] Oxford University Press, 2005. p24 {{ISBN|0-19-280596-7}}, 9780192805966. Accessed at Google Books, 14 December 2013. Esch had also won a competition to design the [[Bengal Club]] building at [[Chowringhee]] and the Bengal-Nagpur Railway head office building at [[Garden Reach (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Garden Reach]]. == Construction == [[File:Victoria Memorial calcutta.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Construction in progress.]] The construction of the Victoria Memorial was delayed by Curzon's from India in 1905 with a subsequent loss of local enthusiasm for the project, and by the need for testing of the foundations. The Victoria Memorial's [[foundation stone]] was set in 1906 and the building opened in 1921.Sharma A. [https://books.google.com/books?id=rTbv4jcRHccC&dq=%22victoria+memorial%22+1921&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Famous monuments of India."] Pinnacle Technology, 2011. {{ISBN|1-61820-545-5}}, 9781618205452. Accessed at Google Books, 14 December 2013. The work of construction was entrusted to [[Martin Burn|Messrs. Martin & Co.]] of Calcutta. Work on the superstructure began in 1910. After 1947, when India gained [[History of the Republic of India|independence]], additions were made. == External decorative features == [[File:Ketan donate5.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Motherhood]] Atop the central dome of the Victoria Memorial is the {{convert|16|ft|m|abbr=on}} figure of [[Nike (mythology)|the Angel of Victory]]. Surrounding the dome are [[allegorical sculpture]]s including ''Art'', ''Architecture'', ''Justice'', and ''Charity'' and above the North Porch are ''Motherhood'', ''Prudence'' and ''Learning''. [[File:Curzon fronting Victoria Memorial.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Statue of [[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston|Curzon]] in front of the Kolkata Victoria Memorial]] === Use of white Makrana Marble === Like the [[Taj Mahal]], the Victoria Memorial is built of white [[Makrana marble]] and is a memorial to an [[empress]]. In design, it echos the Taj Mahal with its dome, four subsidiaries, octagonal-domed [[chattris]], high portals, terrace, and domed corner towers.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} == Exhibitions == [[File:Victoria Memorial Hall 5717.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Gallery]] The Victoria Memorial has 25 galleries.Chander P. [https://books.google.com/books?id=4_Rl5c_v1-kC&dq=%22william+emerson%22+architect+india&source=gbs_navlinks_s "India past and present."] APH Publishing, 2003. p148 {{ISBN|8176484555}}, 9788176484558. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. These include the royal gallery, the national leaders gallery, the portrait gallery, central hall, the sculpture gallery, the arms and armoury gallery and the newer, Calcutta gallery. The Victoria Memorial has the largest single collection of the works of [[Thomas Daniell]] (1749–1840) and his nephew, William Daniell (1769–1837).Freitag W. M. [https://books.google.com/books?id=beHYAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT251&dq=%22thomas+daniell%22+victoria+memorial&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ngasUtzPL8rjkQXMhYDABQ&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22thomas%20daniell%22%20victoria%20memorial&f=false "Art books: a basic bibliography of monographs on artists."] 2503. Victoria Memorial (Calcutta). ''A descriptive catalogue of Daniells work in the Victoria Memorial (Museum). 1976.'' Routledge, 2nd edition, 2013. {{ISBN|1-134-83041-6}}, 9781134830411. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. The Victoria Memorial also has a collection of rare and [[antiquarian]] books such as the illustrated works of [[William Shakespeare]], the ''[[Arabian Nights]]'' and the ''[[Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam|Rubaiyat]]'' by [[Omar Khayyam]] as well as books about [[kathak]] dance and [[thumri]] music by [[Wazid Ali Shah]]. However, the galleries and their exhibitions, the programmatic elements of the memorial do not compete with the purely architectural spaces or voids.Dutta A. [https://books.google.com/books?id=T-cJ1DJHG7IC&dq=%22william+emerson%22+architect+india&source=gbs_navlinks_s "The Bureaucracy of beauty: design in the age of its global reproducability."] Routledge, 2013 p294. {{ISBN|1-135-86402-0}}, 9781135864026. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013.Moorhouse G. [https://books.google.com/books?id=eR0WhGXILVYC&dq=Calcutta+gallery+victoria+memorial&source=gbs_navlinks_s "Calcutta."] Faber & Faber, 2012. {{ISBN|0-571-28113-3}}, 9780571281138. Accessed at Google Books, 13 December 2013. === Royal gallery === The Royal Gallery displays a number of portraits of Victoria and [[Albert, Prince Consort|Prince Albert]], and paintings illustrating their lives, by Jansen and [[Winterhalter]]. The oil paintings are copies of those in London. They include: Victoria receiving the sacrament at her coronation in [[Westminster Abbey]] (June 1838); Victoria's marriage to Albert in the [[Chapel Royal]] at [[St James's Palace]] (1840); the christening of the Prince of Wales in St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle (1842); the marriage of the Prince of Wales (Edward VII) to Princess Alexandra (1863); Victoria at the First Jubilee service at Westminster Abbey (1887) and the Second Jubilee service at [[St. Paul's Cathedral]] (June 1897). Victoria's childhood rosewood [[pianoforte]] and her correspondence desk from [[Windsor Castle]] stand in the centre of the room. Edward VII presented these items to the Victoria Memorial. On the south wall hangs the Russian artist [[Vasily Vereshchagin]]'s oil painting of the state entry of Edward VII, (then Prince of Wales), into [[Jaipur]] in 1876.[http://www.victoriamemorial-cal.org/royalgal.html "The Royal gallery."] ''www.victoriamemorial-cal.org''. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050224035004/http://www.victoriamemorial-cal.org/royalgal.html|date=24 February 2005}} Retrieved 1 January 2017.Dutta A. [http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-otherstates/gallery-reopens-at-victoria-memorial-after-a-decade/article3887521.ece "Gallery reopens at Victoria Memorial after a decade."] ''The Hindu'', 12 September 2012. Accessed 14 December 2013.[http://www.culturalindia.net/monuments/victoria-memorial.html Victoria Memorial Hall.] ''www.culturalindia.net''. Accessed 14 December 2013. === Calcutta gallery === In the mid 1970s, the matter of a new gallery devoted to the visual history of Calcutta was promoted by [[Saiyid Nurul Hasan]], the minister for education. In 1986, Hasan became the governor of [[West Bengal]] and chairman of the board of trustees of the Victoria Memorial. In November 1988, Hasan hosted an international seminar on the ''Historical perspectives for the Calcutta tercentenary''. The Calcutta gallery concept was agreed and a design was developed leading to the opening of the gallery in 1992. The Calcutta gallery houses a visual display of the history and development of Calcutta from [[Job Charnock]] (1630–1692) of the English [[East India Company]] to 1911, when the capital of India was transferred to New Delhi. The gallery also has a life-size [[diorama]] of [[Chitpur]] road in the late 1800s.[http://www.victoriamemorial-cal.org/calgallery.html "Calcutta Gallery."] ''www.victoriamemorial-cal.org''. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422214037/http://www.victoriamemorial-cal.org/calgallery.html|date=22 April 2016}}. Accessed 1 January 2017. == Gardens == The gardens cover an area of {{convert|64|acre|m2}}. They are maintained by a team of 21 gardeners. They were designed by Redesdale and David Prain. On Esch's bridge, between narrative panels by [[Goscombe John]], there is a bronze statue of Victoria, by [[George Frampton]]. Victoria is seated on her throne, wearing the robes of the [[Most Exalted Order of the Star of India|Star of India]]. In the paved quadrangles and elsewhere around the building, other statues commemorate Hastings, [[Charles Cornwallis, 1st Marquess Cornwallis|Charles Cornwallis (1st Marquess Cornwallis)]], [[Robert Clive]], [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Arthur Wellesley]], and [[James Broun-Ramsay, 1st Marquess of Dalhousie]]. Approaching the Victoria Memorial building from the south, visitors pass the Edward VII memorial arch. Upon the arch is a bronze equestrian statue of Edward VII by [[Bertram Mackennal]] and a marble statue of Curzon by [[F. W. Pomeroy|Frederic William Pomeroy]]. The garden contains statues of dignitaries such as [[Lord William Bentinck]], governor-general of India (1833–1835), [[George Robinson, 1st Marquess of Ripon|George Robinson (1st Marquess of Ripon)]], governor-general of India (1880–84), and [[Rajendra Nath Mookerjee]], a pioneer [[industrialist]] of Bengal. == Picture gallery == File:Calcutta Kolkata Victoria Memorial.jpg|Illumination File:Victoria Memorial Hall, Kolkata.jpg|Sunny day File:Kolkata Victoria Memorial South side.JPG|The South side File:Victoria Memorial 03.jpg|Morning, winter day File:Victoria Memorial - Kolkata.jpg|Dusk File:Victoria another perspective.jpg|Main entrance File:Lakes of victoria.jpg|Lakes File:Victoria Memorial SJ.jpg|Victoria Memorial File:Victoria Memorial Kolkata panorama.jpg|Victoria Memorial Kolkata panorama File:Side view of Victoria Memorial.jpg|Side view File:Victoria memorial Kolkata.jpg|Victoria Memorial, Kolkata == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Commons category|Victoria Memorial, Kolkata}} {{Wikivoyage|Kolkata/Maidan}} *{{Official website|www.victoriamemorial-cal.org/}} *[http://indiatourism.ws/kolkata/victoria_memorial/ "360 degree spherical panoramas of Victoria Memorial."] India Tourism. {{Kolkata topics}} {{Tourist attractions in Kolkata}} {{Queen Victoria}} [[Category:1921 establishments in India]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in India]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1921]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Kolkata]] [[Category:City museums]] [[Category:Gardens in India]] [[Category:History of Kolkata]] [[Category:Marble buildings]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials to Queen Victoria]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in West Bengal]] [[Category:Museums established in 1921]] [[Category:Museums in Kolkata]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Kolkata]] [[Category:Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture]] [[Category:National museums of India]]

revision.comment: #WCCWiki - clean up, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: Master's degree → master's degree, Augustine’s → Augustine's (3)
revision.text:
'''Virginia Burrus''' is an American scholar of [[Late Antiquity]] and expert on [[gender]], [[Human sexuality|sexuality]] and [[religion]]. She is currently the Bishop W. Earl Ledden Professor of Religion and Director of Graduate Studies at [[Syracuse University]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://asfaculty.syr.edu/pages/rel/burrus-virginia.html|title=Virginia Burrus|website=asfaculty.syr.edu|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref>
== Education == Originally from Texas, Burrus attended [[Yale University]] where she gained a BA in [[Classical Civilisation|Classical Civilization]] in 1981, before studying in Theology at the [[Georg-August Universität]], Germany (1981-1982).<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://users.drew.edu/vburrus/|title=Virginia Burrus - Drew University|website=users.drew.edu|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref> She then went on to gain an master's degree in 1984 from the [[History of Christianity]] from the [[Graduate Theological Union]] in [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley, CA]].<ref name=":0" /> Her dissertation was entitled ''Chastity as Autonomy: Women in the Stories of the Apocryphal Acts.''<ref>{{Cite thesis|last=Burrus|first=Virginia|title=Chastity as autonomy: women in the stories of the apocryphal Acts|date=1984|url=http://grace.gtu.edu/record=b1080730~S0}}</ref> She received her PhD in 1991 from the same institution. Her doctoral thesis was entitled ''The Making of a Heresy: Authority, Gender, and the Priscillianist Controversy''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Burrus|first1=Virginia|title=The Making of a Heresy: Authority, Gender, and the Priscillianist Controversy|url=https://grace.gtu.edu/search~S0?/Xburrus&SORT=D/Xburrus&SORT=D&SUBKEY=burrus/1%2C39%2C39%2CB/frameset&FF=Xburrus&SORT=D&8%2C8%2C|website=Graduate Theological Union Library Catalogue|access-date=2017-09-15}}</ref> Her PhD was supervised by [[Rebecca Lyman]], Professor Emerita of History at [[University of California, Berkeley]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gtu.edu/news/ancient-texts-fresh-insights-alumna-year-virginia-burrus|title=Ancient Texts, Fresh Insights: Alumna of the Year Virginia Burrus|last=commassistant|date=2018-03-27|work=Graduate Theological Union|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ahma.berkeley.edu/people/faculty/rebecca-lyman|title=Rebecca Lyman {{!}} Ancient History & Mediterranean Archaeology|website=ahma.berkeley.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref>
== Career == Burrus was Professor of Early Church History at [[Drew University]] from 1991 to 2013 (Assistant Professor, 1991-1996; Associate Professor, 1996-2003; Chair of the Graduate Division of Religion, 2009-2013).<ref name=":0" /> On joining Syracuse University as the Bishop W. Earl Ledden Professor of Religion, Burrus was the third person to be appointed to the position and succeeded [[Patricia Cox Miller]], Professor Emerita at Syracuse University.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gtu.edu/news/alumna-burrus-accepts-appointment-syracuse-university|title=Alumna Burrus accepts appointment at Syracuse University|last=T324Admin|date=2013-07-30|work=Graduate Theological Union|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thecollege.syr.edu/people/faculty/pages/rel/miller-patricia.html|title=Patricia Cox Miller|website=thecollege.syr.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref> Burrus was appointed Director of Graduate Studies at Syracuse University in 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gtu.edu/news/dr-virginia-burrus-named-2017-gtu-alumna-year|title=Dr. Virginia Burrus Named 2017 GTU Alumna of the Year|last=communications|date=2017-09-01|work=Graduate Theological Union|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en}}</ref>
Burrus is a member of several academic societies, including the [[American Academy of Religion]] (1985–present) and the [[Society of Biblical Literature]] (1985–present), and has sat on steering committees for both associations.<ref name="Burrus CV">{{cite web|last1=Burrus|first1=Virginia|title=Academic CV|url=http://asfaculty.syr.edu/pages/rel/_CVs/burrus-virginiaCV.pdf}}</ref> She has been elected as a member of the [[American Theological Society]] (2002), the American Society of the Study of Religion (2005) and the International Association of Patristic Studies (2010). From 2009-10 she served as the president of the North American Patristics Association, of which she remains a member. Burrus has served as an associate editor for the ''Journal of Early Christian Studies'' (2008-2014), and is the founding co-editor of the [[University of Pennsylvania]] Press Series ''Divinations: Rereading Late Ancient Religion'' (2001–present).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://users.drew.edu/vburrus/|title=Virginia Burrus - Drew University|website=users.drew.edu|access-date=2016-11-02}}</ref>
Professor Burrus specializes in the literary and cultural history of [[Christianity]], and has a wide range of interests including [[gender]], [[Human sexuality|sexuality]], [[orthodoxy]] and [[heresy]], [[martyr]]dom, [[asceticism]], [[hagiography]] and histories of [[theology]] within Late Antiquity.<ref name=":0" /> Burrus engages with a variety of theoretical discourses within her work, including [[feminism]] and [[post-colonialism]], applying and critiquing the approaches of 20th century philosophers and theorists such as [[Baudrillard]], [[Cixous]], [[Michel Foucault|Foucault]] and [[Irigaray]].<ref name="Krondorfer 2006">{{cite journal|last1=Krondorfer|first1=Bjorn|title=The Sex Lives of Saints: An Erotics of Ancient Hagiography (review)|journal=Journal of the American Academy of Religion|date=8 May 2006|volume=74|issue=1|pages=259–262|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/196811|issn=1477-4585}}</ref> Her 2004 publication ''The Sex Lives of the Saints'' has been translated into French, Italian and Czech.<ref name=":0" />
[[File:Burrus - Begotten Not Made.jpg|thumb|Front cover of Prof. Burrus' book '"Begotten Not Made". Conceiving Manhood in Late Antiquity']]
==Select bibliography==
=== Books and edited volumes === * Czech translation: Sexuální životy svatých: Erotika středověké hagiografie, translated by Zuzana Gabajová. Prague: Academia, 2015 * ''The Life of Saint Helia: Critical Edition, Translation, Introduction, and Commentary''. Early Christian Texts. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014. (Co-author with Marco Conti) * French translation: ''La vie sexuelle des saints: L’art érotique de l’hagiographie ancienne'', translated by Elsa Boyer. Montrouge: Bayard, 2011 * Italian translation: ''La vita erotica dei Santi'', translated by Marta Albertella. Genova: Il Melangolo, 2011 *''Seducing Augustine: Bodies, Desires, Confessions''. NY: Fordham University Press, 2010. (Co-author with Mark Jordan and Karmen MacKendrick) * ''Saving Shame: Martyrs, Saints, and Other Abject Subjects'.' Divinations: Rereading Late Ancient Religion. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2008. * ''Toward a Theology of Eros''. NY: Fordham University Press, 2006. (Co-editor with [[Catherine Keller (theologian)|Catherine Keller]]) * ''Late Ancient Christianity: A People’s History of Christianity, Volume 2''. Minneapolis: Fortress Press, 2005. (Editor) * ''The Sex Lives of Saints: An Erotics of Ancient Hagiography''. Divinations: Rereading Late Ancient Religion. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2004. * ''“Begotten, Not Made”: Conceiving Manhood in Late Antiquity''. Figurae: Reading Medieval Culture. Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2000. * ''The Making of a Heretic: Gender, Authority, and the Priscillianist Controversy''. Transformation of the Classical Heritage. Berkeley: University of California Press, 1995. * ''Chastity as Autonomy: Women in the Stories of Apocryphal Acts''. Women in Religion. Lewiston & Queenston: The Edwin Mellen Press, 1987.
===Articles and essays=== * "Socrates, the Rabbis and the Virgin: The Dialogic Imagination in Late Antiquity". [[Charlotte Fonrobert|Charlotte Elisheva Fonrobert]], Ishay Rosen-Zvi, Aharon Shemesh & Moulie Vidas (eds.) in collaboration with James Redfield, ''Talmudic Transgressions: Engaging the Work of Daniel Boyarin''. Leiden: Brill (2017), 457-74 * “Torture, Truth, and the Witnessing Body: Reading Christian Martyrdom with [[Page DuBois|Page duBois]],” in ''Torture, Truth, and Slavery: Engaging the Work of Page duBois'', ed. by Albert Harrill, special issue of ''Biblical Interpretation: A Journal of Contemporary Issues'', 25.1 (2017) * With Marco Conti, “Between Fragment and Compilation: A Virgin’s Vision of the Afterlife,” ''Sacris Erudiri'' 54 (2015) 201-224 * “‘Nec sanabatur vulnus illud meum’ (Conf. 6.15): Trauma, Time, and Voice in Augustine's Confessions,” ''Trauma and Traumatization in Individual and Collective Dimensions: Insights from Biblical Studies and Beyond'', ed. by Eve-Marie Becker, Jan Dochhorn, and Else Holt (Göttingen: Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht, 2014), 100-110 * “History, Theology, Orthodoxy, Polydoxy", ''Modern Theology'' 30 (2014) 7-16 * “Gender, Eros, and Pedagogy: Macrina’s Pious Household”, ''Ascetic Culture'', edited by Blake Leyerle and Robin Darling Young, University of Notre Dame Press, 2013, 167-81 * “Seducing Theology”, ''Theology and Sexuality'' 18:2 (2013) * “Augustine, Rosenzweig, and the Possibility of Experiencing Miracle”, ''Material Spirit'', edited by Carl Good, Manuel Asensi, and Gregory Stallings. New York: Fordham University Press, 2013, 94-110 * “Nothing is Not One: Revisiting the ex nihilo.” ''Modern Theology'' 29.2 (2013): 33-48 *“‘Honor the Fathers’: Exegesis and Authority in the Life of Saint Helia.” ''Asceticism and Exegesis in Early Christianity: The Reception of New Testament Texts in Ancient Ascetic Discourses'', edited by Hans-Ulrich Wiedemann. Göttingen, Germany: Vandenhoeck and Ruprecht, 2013, 445-57 * “‘The Passover Still Takes Place Today’: Exegesis, Asceticism, Judaism, and Origen's On Passover.” ''Asceticism and Exegesis in Early Christianity: The Reception of New Testament Texts in Ancient Ascetic Discourses'', edited by Hans-Ulrich Wiedemann. Göttingen, Germany: Vandenhoeck and Ruprecht, 2013, 235-45 * “Bodies, Desires, Confessions: Shame in Plotinus, Antony, and Augustine”, ''Shame Between Penance and Punishment'', edited by Bénédicte Sère and Jörg Wettlaufer. Florence: SISMEL-Edizioni del Galluzzo, 2013, 23-48 * “Augustine’s Bible”, ''Ideology, Culture, and Translation'', edited by Scott Elliott and Roland Boer. Atlanta: Society of Biblical Literature, 2012, 69-82 * "Wyschogrod's Hand: Saints, Animality, and the Labor of Love", ''Philosophy Today'' (Winter 2011): 412-421 * “Seeing God in Bodies: Augustine, Rosenzweig, Wolfson”, ''Reading Forwards and Backwards: Postmodern Readings of Ancient Christian Texts'', edited by Scot Douglass and Morwenna Ludlow. London: T&T Clark, 2011, 44-59 * “2010 NAPS Presidential Address: ‘Fleeing the Uxorious Kingdom’: Augustine's Queer Theology of Marriage”, ''Journal of Early Christian Studies'' 19 (2011): 1-20 * “A Saint of One’s Own: Emmanuel Levinas, Eliezer ben Hyrcanus, and Eulalia of Mérida”, ''L'Esprit Créateur'' 50 (2010): 6-20. Special issue on “Sanctity,” edited by Cary Howie * “Carnal Excess: Flesh at the Limits of Imagination”, ''Journal of Early Christian Studies'' 17 (2009): 247-265 * "Queer Lives of Saints: Jerome's Hagiography", ''Journal of the History of Sexuality'', vol. 10 (2001) 442-479 * "Words and Flesh: The Bodies and Sexuality of Ascetic Women in Christian Antiquity", ''Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion'', vol. 10 (1994) 27-51

{{BLP unsourced|date=June 2018}} '''Vyronas Davos''' (Greek: Βύρων Δάβος), b. 1927 is a [[Greece|Greek]] [[historian]], [[writer]] and [[poet]]. He was born in the village of [[Pelopio]] in [[Elis (regional unit)|Elis]] and moved to [[Athens]] as an employee of the fire department. Davos was member of the Hellenic or Greek Literature Company and the Greek Literature Union. His literature of the same is made known to the cultural ministry. ==Bibliography== He wrote several historic and poetic works. His most popular include: {| class="wikitable" ! Year !! Title !! English title !! Category |- | 1945 || ''Χρόνοι σκλαβιάς'' || ''Slavery Times'' || - |- | 1951 || ''Ήρθαν τα χελιδόνια'' || ''Here Comes The [[Turtle]]'' || - |- | 1957 ||''Μακρυνές αγάπες'' || ''Everlasting Love'' || - |- | 1959 || ''Ήχοι και αντίλαλοι'' || - || - |- | 1971 || ''Η μεγάλη επιστροφή'' || ''The Big Return'' || - |- | 1974 || ''Η ιστορία του χωριού μου''
''Όσα γράφει η μοίρα'' || ''History Of My Town''
- || -
- |- | 1995 || ''Ιστορία του Πύργου Ηλείας'' || ''History of [[Pyrgos, Elis]]'' || historical |- | 1996 || ''Στον Πύργο και στην Ηλεία του 1821-1930'' || ''In Pyrgos and in Elis (1821-1930) || historical |- | 1997 || ''Η ιστορία της πυροσβεστικής υπηρεσίας 1830-1980''
''η Ηλεία πρίν την επανάσταση του 1821''
''η ζωή των κατοίκων της Ηλείας κατα την τουρκοκρατία''
''Τα σταφιδικά της Ηλείας'' || ''History Of The Fire Department (1830-1980)
''Elis Before The [[Greek War of Independence|Revolution]] of 1821
''The Life Of The Inhabitants Of Elis During The [[Turkey|Turkish]] Rule''
- || historical
historical
historical
- |- | - || ''Τοπονύμια της Ηλείας'' || ''Toponyms of Elis'' || |- | - || ''Φωνες απ'τ'άστρα'' || - || - |- |} He also wrote several articles in newspapers of Elis including ''[[Patris (newspaper)|Patris]]'', ''[[I Avgi|Avgi]]'', etc. ==References== *''The first version of the article is translated from the [[:el:Βύρων Δάβος|article]] at the Greek Wikipedia ([[:el:|Main page]])'' {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Davos Vyronas}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Olympia, Greece]] [[Category:Greek historians]] [[Category:Greek journalists]] [[Category:20th-century Greek poets]] [[Category:Greek writers]] [[Category:Greek male poets]] [[Category:20th-century male writers]]
